awd_abstract_narration:
Ion-containing polymer membranes are critical components in many technologies including chemical separations, water purification, fuel cells, and other energy generation and storage devices. In solar-fuel devices, ion-containing polymer membranes are responsible for permitting the selective transport of ions between electrodes to maintain overall charge neutrality yet limit the transport of oxidation and reduction products produced at the electrodes. Improvements in membrane technology for these applications requires new material development that will rely on fundamental understanding of the relationships between polymer membrane structure and the transport of ions, molecules and complex mixtures. This project leverages a tunable membrane design strategy to investigate fundamental relationships between membrane structure, membrane physicochemical properties, and membrane-transport behavior of ion-containing polymer membranes. Results from this study will provide fundamental structure-property relations which will guide the future design of ion-containing polymer membranes. The research will train undergraduate and graduate students in cutting edge research in membrane science and engage students from underrepresented groups in STEM fields. The investigators will also develop and disseminate hands-on educational and outreach activities, including undergraduate independent study experiences and exploratory modules related to STEM and membrane science through summer research experiences and primary education outreach including summer engineering camps for high school students.

The goal of this research is to elucidate how co-transporting neutral species impact the transport of charged species in ion containing polymer membranes with membrane-bound anions (cation exchange membranes). The research hypothesis is that the presence of neutral species reduces electrostatic interactions (i.e. Donnan exclusion) that occur between membrane-bound sulfonate anions and permeating anions, leading to increased permeability of the charged solute. PEGDA-based membranes with systematically varied membrane structure, fractional free volume, and ion content will be synthesized and the impact of membrane chemistry on physiochemical properties will be characterized. Fundamental solute-solute and solute-membrane interactions will be systematically elucidated using a tunable synthetic design strategy based on photopolymerization of acrylates and diacrylates to control polymer membrane structure, bound ion content, and water uptake. Transport properties (i.e. permeability, solubility, and diffusivity) will be investigated experimentally for a neutral solute (methanol), an ionic solute (acetate), and their complex mixture. Permeation experiments will be conducted using custom-built diffusion cells outfitted to monitor receiver cell solute concentrations using ATR FTIR spectroscopy enabling simultaneous characterization of multiple simultaneous solute concentrations. This research will have the potential to impact the design of new membrane materials for a variety of applications, such as materials for water purification, and energy devices such as solar fuels devices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Electrochemical CO2 reduction is an attractive strategy to tackle the CO2 emission problem in the environment. A typical CO2 reduction cell consists of two half cells, an anode, and a cathode, separated by ion exchange membranes (IEM). Electrochemical CO2 reduction is fundamentally a complicated process that follows multi-electron and proton pathways and produces several products. As some of the products cross through the ion exchange membrane (IEM), product crossover is one of the limitations of such electrochemical cells, reducing device efficiency. As these product molecules must diffuse through the IEMS to reach the opposing cell, understanding the fundamental structure-property-transport behavior relationships of IEMs is critical. This project investigated the relationships between polymer membrane chemistry, physiochemical properties (water uptake, ion exchange capacity, swelling behavior), and molecular transport properties (permeability, solubility, and diffusivity) to understand how co-transporting neutral species impact the transport of charged species in polymer membranes. 


In this project we synthesized a series of crosslinked polymer membranes with different chemistries and characterized the resulting physical properties and transport properties. Permeability was characterized for aqueous solutions of a series of alcohols and carboxylates as well as their complex mixtures (aqueous alcohol and carboxylate together) where the cotransport behavior was characterized using custom diffusion cells outfitted with in situ ATR FTIR spectroscopy. The key outcomes from this project include the following. The amount of water within the hydrated membrane, a key factor for transport behavior, can be controlled systematically both through the polymer membrane chemistry but also independent of the membrane chemistry through control over the membrane synthesis process. Incorporation of a longer chain neutral comonomer such as poly(ethylene glycol) methacrylate, significantly suppresses the crossover of carboxylates in co-transport with methanol compared to incorporation of shorter chain comonomers (acrylic acid and hydroxyethyl methacrylate). This behavior was also observed for PEGMA with an two different side chain lengths as well as other neutral PEGMA-based comonomers of similar length but with a different chain end chemistry (methyl group in lieu of hydroxyl groups). Interestingly, the methyl-terminal comonomer incorporated in cation exchange membranes displayed improved ionic conductivity while also reducing carboxylate crossover in cotransport with alcohols.


The membranes studied in this project provide for future opportunities to improve membrane design for the manipulation of transport and cotransport behavior with implications in applications areas including water purification, fuel cells, and industrial separations. The project provided opportunities for research, teaching and mentoring in chemical engineering, materials science, and membrane science. It trained two PhD (including one from an underrepresented group) and 5 undergraduate researchers (2 of which were from underrepresented groups). The results of this project have been disseminated through 6 manuscripts published in peer-reviewed journals reporting on the results obtained in this project. The principal investigator, graduate and undergraduate students also presented the research at regional, and national conferences (7 conference presentations).


Last Modified: 09/17/2024
Modified by: Bryan S Beckingham

Image
  • Manipulation of Crosslinked membrane chemistry allows independent control over water content and through longer side-chain comonomers such as PEGMA can reduce carboxylate permeability in cotransport with methanol
    Antara Mazumder
